items.description: Lower Stour and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.55 m and is falling slowly. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.25 m and is falling slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load if this level exceeds 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.  No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   The River Yeo at Muchelney has been decreasing throughout today. We are continuing to monitor the situation closely. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 15:00 on Friday, 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Derwent Water Lake levels remain high following recent rainfall with water levels remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses.  Flooding is likely to continue to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. With a dry forecast until  Saturday levels will continue to recede. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Friday 05/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels continue to remain high as a result of recent rainfall, although they are starting to recede and will continue to recede due to a dry forecast up until Saturday. These include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Friday 05/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.85 m and is falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.00 m and is falling slowly. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Pumping is now taking place at Currymoor pumping station, as well as Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. The two Currymoor pumps will run while river Tone levels allow, to avoid water spilling back into the Moor. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 15:00 on Friday, 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We will monitor the weather and reissue this flood alert as necessary. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and be aware of your local weather forecasts.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and we will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Esk catchment
items.message: The flood alert for the river Esk remains in force. River levels have risen on the River Esk due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Low lying land in the Esk Valley, particularly around Ruswarp and some minor roads. No further rainfall is forecast and levels are expected to reduce. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Seven catchment
items.message: The flood alert for the River Seven catchment remains in force. River levels have risen in this area as a result of recent rainfall on Wednesday 4th November. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during Thursday. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and we will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.75mAOD at 14:00 on 04/11/21 and 4.90mAOD at 02:15 on 05/11/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 80 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:30pm Thursday 4 November and 12:30am tomorrow. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.93 mAODN at 11:30pm, on Thursday 4 November, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 09:30am tomorrow, Friday 5 November.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Thursday 4th November between 15:45 and 18:15 and tomorrow, Friday 5th November between 04:00-06:15. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 22:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Thursday 4th November between 15:45 and 18:30 and tomorrow, Friday 5th November between 04:00-06:45 and 16:45-19:15. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 22:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast tomorrow morning, Friday 5th November. Overtopping waves and spray are expected to affect the frontages and promenades in Hornsea, particularly in the area around Marine Drive and South Promenade between 03:45 and 05:15am. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this warning for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, promenades coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 22:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast tomorrow morning, Friday 5th November between 03:45 and 05:15. The particular areas at risk are exposed area frontages in Hornsea. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, promenades coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 22:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of large and powerful waves overtopping sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. Our incident duty team will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Large waves are likely to cause sea spray to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir as a result of high tides.  Forecast high water is 18:15 on 04/11/21 with a level of 6.35 mAOD and a Force 4 Northerley wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.   Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tide.
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated Friday, 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of strong onshore winds. Tides will be at their highest at 06:00am tomorrow morning, 05/11/21. Flooding to the promenade/seafront is possible at this time, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. It is possible flooding could affect Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of strong onshore winds. Tides will be at their highest at 06:00am tomorrow morning, 05/11/21. Flooding to the promenade/seafront is possible at this time, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. It is possible flooding could affect Hunstanton seafront.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:30pm on Thursday 4 November and 12:30am tomorrow. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.60 mAODN at 11:30pm, on Thursday 4 November, which is 0.39m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 09:30am tomorrow, Friday 5 November.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 10:30pm Thursday 4th November and 12:30am tomorrow. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.60mAODN at 11:30pm, on Thursday 4th November, which is 0.39m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 09:30am tomorrow.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 11:00pm Thursday 4th November and 1:00am tomorrow. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.42mAODN at midnight tonight, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 10:00am tomorrow.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.93 mAODN at 11:30pm, on Thursday 4 November, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 09:30am tomorrow, Friday 5 November.

items.description: Coast from Whitstable to Margate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood alert has been issued due to a high tide forecast for Friday Morning, 05/11/2021. Highest tide is expected to be at 00:15 on Friday. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time from 22:15 to 02:15. Flooding to properties is not expected.
Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond if required.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. For those who need it, the forecast total water height at Sheerness for the 00:15 Friday morning tide is 3.54mAOD.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest throughout the morning at 11:00 AM on 05/11/2021.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 11:00 AM on 05/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 05/11/2021, or as the situation changes.
